question: Welcome to Our User Survey on Explainable AI and Decision Trees
description:
Thank you for participating in our research survey! This study is part of a thesis project focused on Explainable AI, specifically exploring decision trees.

In this survey, you will be represented with 4 different datasets.

For each dataset you will be provided by a description and a decision tree will be displayed.

Your task is to classify 5 samples of the dataset based on the decision tree displayed.

During the classification tasks, we will measure the time taken for each classification. Please proceed efficiently and avoid unnecessary delays.

After that you will be asked to measure the confidence of your answers, the trust you have in the model and provide a small description of the model.

Feel free to add any comments you want!

Your participation in this survey is entirely voluntary. You are free to stop at any time without any consequences. There is no reward or profit for participating in this survey.

Your responses will greatly contribute to our research and understanding of Explainable AI.

question: Play Tennis Dataset Example
description:
The Play Tennis dataset is a simple and classic example used in machine learning to demonstrate decision tree algorithms. This dataset contains information about weather conditions and whether or not tennis was played on a given day. The goal is to predict if tennis will be played based on certain weather conditions.

Attributes:

Attribute Description
Outlook The weather outlook, which can be 'Sunny', 'Overcast', or 'Rain' (categorical).
Temperature The temperature on that day, categorized as 'Hot', 'Mild', or 'Cool' (categorical).
Humidity The humidity level, either 'High' or 'Normal' (categorical).
Windy Whether the wind is 'True' or 'False' (categorical).

Goal:

Whether tennis was played or not, represented as 'Yes' or 'No'.

In this example, you will be given various weather conditions, and your task is to determine whether tennis will be played based on the provided decision tree. Please analyze the decision tree carefully and classify each sample accordingly.

Before starting the classification task, please use the zoom functionality to examine the decision tree and understand how it works.

Remember, this is an example Take all the time necessary to get familiar with the process

question: Will tennis be played under these weather conditions?
description:
The green button zooms in

The red button zooms out

The yellow button reverts zooming

You can also zoom in and out by clicking.

In the decision tree, you may encounter nodes with splits that include a category labeled "Other". This category represents any value that is not explicitly listed in the other split categories. For example, if you see a node with the attribute "Temperature" and splits into "Hot" and "Other," any temperature value that is not "Hot" should follow the "Other" branch.

Example of classification data:

Outlook Temperature Humidity Windy
Sunny Hot High False

question: Survey is About to Begin
description:
Thank you for completing the example classification task.

The survey will start from the next question.

Remember, the time taken for each classification will be measured, so proceed efficiently.

question: COMPAS Dataset
description:
The COMPAS (Correctional Offender Management Profiling for Alternative Sanctions) dataset is used to predict the likelihood of a defendant re-offending within two years.

Attributes:

Attribute Description
sex The sex of the defendant (e.g., Male, Female).
age The age of the defendant at the time of the crime.
race The race of the defendant (e.g., Caucasian, African-American).
juv_fel_count The number of juvenile felony charges the defendant has.
juv_misd_count The number of juvenile misdemeanor charges the defendant has.
juv_other_count The number of other juvenile charges the defendant has.
priors_count The number of prior criminal charges the defendant has.
c_charge_degree The degree of the current charge (e.g., Misdemeanor, Felony).
two_year_recid A binary variable indicating whether the defendant recidivated (re-offended) within two years (1: Yes, 0: No).

Goal:

The goal of analyzing the COMPAS dataset is to predict the likelihood of a defendant re-offending within two years based on their demographic information and criminal history.

There will be 5 classification tasks following, where the time taken for each task is important. Please proceed efficiently.

question: Could you describe in a few words the model?
German Credit Dataset
description:
The German Credit dataset is used to assess the creditworthiness of individuals applying for credit. This dataset contains various attributes related to the demographic and financial information of applicants. Financial institutions use this information to evaluate the risk associated with lending to these individuals.

Attributes:

Attribute Description
Age The age of the individual in years (numeric).
Sex The sex of the individual (text: male, female).
Job The type of job the individual has (numeric: 0 - unskilled and non-resident, 1 - unskilled and resident, 2 - skilled, 3 - highly skilled).
Housing The type of housing the individual resides in (text: own, rent, or free).
Saving accounts The amount of savings the individual has (text: little, moderate, quite rich, rich).
Checking account The amount in the individual's checking account (numeric, in Deutsch Mark).
Credit amount The amount of credit the individual has applied for (numeric, in Deutsch Mark).
Duration The duration of the credit in months (numeric).
Purpose The purpose for which the credit is requested (text: car, furniture/equipment, radio/TV, domestic appliances, repairs, education, business, vacation/others).

Goal:

The goal of analyzing the German Credit dataset is to predict the creditworthiness of individuals based on their demographic information and financial attributes. This prediction helps in assessing the risk posed by the individual when applying for credit, which can be used in decision-making processes within financial institutions.

There will be 5 classification tasks following, where the time taken for each task is important. Please proceed efficiently.

question: Could you describe in a few words the model?
Framingham heart study Dataset
description:
The Framingham Heart Study dataset is used to predict the risk of developing coronary heart disease (CHD) based on various health and demographic attributes. This dataset contains information from a long-term cardiovascular cohort study involving residents of Framingham, Massachusetts.

Attributes:

Attribute Description
Age The age of the participant in years (numeric).
Sex The sex of the participant (binary: male, female).
Education The level of education (ordinal: 1 - some high school, 2 - high school or GED, 3 - some college or vocational school, 4 - college).
Current Smoker Whether the participant is a current smoker (binary: 0 - no, 1 - yes).
Cigarettes per Day The number of cigarettes the participant smokes per day (numeric).
BP Meds Whether the participant is on blood pressure medication (binary: 0 - no, 1 - yes).
Prevalent Stroke Whether the participant has had a stroke (binary: 0 - no, 1 - yes).
Prevalent Hypertension Whether the participant has hypertension (binary: 0 - no, 1 - yes).
Diabetes Whether the participant has diabetes (binary: 0 - no, 1 - yes).
Total Cholesterol Total cholesterol level in mg/dL (numeric).
Systolic BP Systolic blood pressure in mmHg (numeric).
Diastolic BP Diastolic blood pressure in mmHg (numeric).
BMI Body mass index (numeric).
Heart Rate Heart rate in beats per minute (numeric).
Glucose Glucose level in mg/dL (numeric).
Ten Year CHD 10-year risk of coronary heart disease (binary: 0 - no, 1 - yes).

Goal:

The goal of analyzing the Framingham Heart Study dataset is to predict the 10-year risk of developing coronary heart disease (CHD) based on various health and demographic attributes. This prediction helps in assessing the risk and taking preventive measures to reduce the likelihood of developing CHD.

There will be 5 classification tasks following, where the time taken for each task is important. Please proceed efficiently.

question: Could you describe in a few words the model?
Adult Income Dataset
description:
The Adult Income dataset, also known as the Census Income dataset, is used to predict whether an individual's annual income exceeds $50,000 based on various demographic and employment attributes. This dataset is often used in classification tasks to analyze income distribution and socio-economic factors.

Attributes:

Attribute Description
Age The age of the individual (numeric).
Workclass The type of employment (e.g., Private, Self-emp-not-inc, etc).
Education The highest level of education attained (e.g., Bachelors, Some-college, etc).
Education-num The number of years of education (numeric).
Marital-status The marital status of the individual (e.g., Married-civ-spouse, Divorced, etc).
Occupation The type of job (e.g., Tech-support, Craft-repair, etc).
Relationship Relationship to the household (e.g., Own-child, Married, etc).
Race The race of the individual (e.g., White, Asian-Pac-Islander, etc).
Sex The sex of the individual (e.g., Male, Female).
Capital-gain Capital gains (numeric).
Capital-loss Capital losses (numeric).
Hours-per-week Hours worked per week (numeric).
Native-country Country of origin (e.g., United-States, Cambodia, etc.).
Income Whether the individual's income exceeds $50,000/year (binary: <=50K, >50K).

Goal:

The goal of analyzing the Adult Income dataset is to predict whether an individual's annual income exceeds $50,000 based on their demographic and employment attributes. This prediction helps in understanding the factors that contribute to higher income and addressing socio-economic disparities.

There will be 5 classification tasks following, where the time taken for each task is important. Please proceed efficiently.
